title: Genre Beats
description: Explore the signature drum feels of rock, hip-hop, jazz, and electronic music.

steps.title: Drums Define the Genre
steps.description: Different music genres have distinctive drum patterns. By changing which pads you emphasize and how you combine them, you can shift between rock, hip-hop, jazz, and electronic feels. Let's explore the key combinations for each genre.

steps.title: Rock: Power and Drive
steps.description: Rock uses kick, snare, and hi-hat as the core. The kick is strong on 1 and 3, the snare punches on 2 and 4, and the hi-hat keeps a steady pulse. Crashes mark transitions.

steps.title: Rock Feel: Kick + Hi-Hat
steps.description: Beat 1 of a rock pattern: kick with closed hi-hat.

steps.title: Hip-Hop: Boom-Clap
steps.description: Hip-hop emphasizes the kick and clap/snare. Patterns are often sparser, with a heavy kick and sharp clap. Open hi-hats add swing.

steps.title: Hip-Hop Feel: Kick + Clap + Open HH
steps.description: A hip-hop accent: kick, clap, and open hi-hat together.
steps.hint: Hit KCK, OHH, and CLP together.

steps.title: Jazz: Ride and Swing
steps.description: Jazz features the ride cymbal as the primary timekeeper. The kick is soft and 'feathered'. Cross-stick snare patterns and brush strokes create a smooth, swinging feel.

steps.title: Jazz Feel: Kick + Ride
steps.description: The jazz foundation: a light kick with the ride cymbal.

steps.title: Electronic: Layers and Energy
steps.description: Electronic music layers many sounds together. Kick and clap are core, with both closed and open hi-hats, and crash cymbals for builds.

steps.title: Electronic Feel: Kick + Clap + CHH
steps.hint: Hit KCK, CHH, and CLP together.
